machine_start_gcode.default:
G28 ; Home
G1 Z15.0 F6000 ;move the platform down 15mm
;Prime the extruder
G92 E0
G1 F200 E3
G92 E0

machine_end_gcode.default:
M104 S0
M140 S0
;Retract the filament
G92 E1
G1 E-1 F300
G28 X0 Y0
M84

layer_height.label: Layer Height
layer_height.description:
Layer height in millimeters.
This is the most important setting to determine the quality of your print. Normal quality prints are 0.1mm, high quality is 0.06mm. You can go up to 0.25mm with an Ultimaker for very fast prints at low quality.

layer_height_0.label: Initial Layer Thickness
layer_height_0.description: Layer thickness of the bottom layer. A thicker bottom layer makes sticking to the bed easier.

shell_thickness.label: Shell Thickness
shell_thickness.description:
Thickness of the outside shell in the horizontal and vertical direction.
This is used in combination with the nozzle size to define the number
of perimeter lines and the thickness of those perimeter lines.
This is also used to define the number of solid top and bottom layers.

wall_thickness.label: Wall Thickness
wall_thickness.description:
Thickness of the outside walls in the horizontal direction.
This is used in combination with the nozzle size to define the number
of perimeter lines and the thickness of those perimeter lines.

wall_line_count.label: Wall Line Count
wall_line_count.description: Amount of wall lines. This these lines are called perimeter lines in other tools and impact the strength and structural integrity of your print.
wall_line_count.inherit_function: max(1, (int(parent_value / (machine_nozzle_size - 0.0001) + 1) if (parent_value / max(1, int(parent_value / (machine_nozzle_size - 0.0001))) > machine_nozzle_size) * 1.5 else int(parent_value / (machine_nozzle_size - 0.0001))))

wall_line_width.label: Wall Line Width
wall_line_width.description: Width of a single wall line. Each wall line will be printed with this width in mind.

wall_line_width_0.label: First Wall Line Width
wall_line_width_0.description: Width of the outer wall line. By printing a thinner first wall line you can print higher details with a larger nozzle.

wall_line_width_x.label: Other Walls Line Width
wall_line_width_x.description: Width of a single wall line for all the other lines except the outer one.

top_bottom_thickness.label: Bottom/Top Thickness
top_bottom_thickness.description:
This controls the thickness of the bottom and top layers, the amount of solid layers put down is calculated by the layer thickness and this value.
Having this value a multiple of the layer thickness makes sense. And keep it near your wall thickness to make an evenly strong part.

top_thickness.label: Top Thickness
top_thickness.description:
This controls the thickness of the top layers, the amount of solid layers put down is calculated by the layer thickness and this value.
Having this value a multiple of the layer thickness makes sense. And keep it near your wall thickness to make an evenly strong part.

top_layers.label: Top Layers
top_layers.description: This controls the amount of top layers.

bottom_thickness.label: Bottom Thickness
bottom_thickness.description:
This controls the thickness of the bottom layers, the amount of solid layers put down is calculated by the layer thickness and this value.
Having this value a multiple of the layer thickness makes sense. And keep it near your wall thickness to make an evenly strong part.

bottom_layers.label: Bottom Layers
bottom_layers.description: This controls the amount of bottom layers.

top_bottom_pattern.label: Bottom/Top Pattern
top_bottom_pattern.description: Pattern of the top/bottom filling. This normally is done with lines to get the best possible filling. But in some cases a concentric fill gives a nicer end result finish.

material_print_temperature.label: Printing Temperature
material_print_temperature.description:
Temperature used for printing. Set at 0 to pre-heat yourself.
For PLA a value of 210C is usually used.
For ABS a value of 230C or higher is required.

material_bed_temperature.label: Bed Temperature
material_bed_temperature.description: Temperature used for the heated printer bed. Set at 0 to pre-heat yourself.

material_diameter.label: Diameter
material_diameter.description:
Diameter of your filament, as accurately as possible.
If you cannot measure this value you will have to calibrate it, a higher number means less extrusion, a smaller number generates more extrusion.

material_flow.label: Flow
material_flow.description: Flow compensation, the amount of material extruded is multiplied by this value

retraction_enable.label: Enable Retraction
retraction_enable.description: Retract the filament when the nozzle is moving over a none-printed area. Details about the retraction can be configured in the advanced tab.

retraction_speed.label: Retraction Speed
retraction_speed.description: Speed at which the filament is retracted, a higher retraction speed works better. But a very high retraction speed can lead to filament grinding.

retraction_amount.label: Retraction Distance
retraction_amount.description: Amount of retraction, set at 0 for no retraction at all. A value of 4.5mm seems to generate good results for 3mm filament.

retraction_min_travel.label: Retraction Minimum Travel
retraction_min_travel.description: Minimum amount of travel needed for a retraction to happen at all. To make sure you do not get a lot of retractions in a small area.

retraction_combing.label: Enable Combing
retraction_combing.description: Combing is the act of avoiding holes in the print for the head to travel over. If combing is disabled the printer head moves straight from the start point to the end point and it will always retract.

retraction_minimal_extrusion.label: Minimal Retraction Before Extrusion
retraction_minimal_extrusion.description:
The minimal amount of extrusion that needs to be done before retracting again if a retraction needs to happen before this minimal is reached the retraction is ignored.
This avoids retracting a lot on the same piece of filament which flattens the filament and causes grinding issues.

retraction_hop.label: Z Hop when Retracting
retraction_hop.description: When a retraction is done, the head is lifted by this amount to travel over the print. A value of 0.075 works well. This feature has a lot of positive effect on delta towers.

speed_print.label: Print Speed
speed_print.description: Speed at which printing happens. A well adjusted Ultimaker can reach 150mm/s, but for good quality prints you want to print slower. Printing speed depends on a lot of factors. So you will be experimenting with optimal settings for this.

speed_infill.label: Infill Speed
speed_infill.description: Speed at which infill parts are printed. Printing the infill faster can greatly reduce printing time, but this can negatively affect print quality.

speed_wall.label: Shell Speed
speed_wall.description: Speed at which shell is printed. Printing the outer shell at a lower speed improves the final skin quality.

speed_wall_0.label: Outer Shell Speed
speed_wall_0.description: Speed at which outer shell is printed. Printing the outer shell at a lower speed improves the final skin quality. However, having a large difference between the inner shell speed and the outer shell speed will effect quality in a negative way.

speed_wall_x.label: Inner Shell Speed
speed_wall_x.description: Speed at which inner shells are printed. Printing the inner shell faster then the outer shell will reduce printing time. It is good to set this somewhere in between the outer shell speed and the infill/printing speed.

speed_support.label: Support Speed
speed_support.description: Speed at which exterior support is printed. Printing exterior supports at higher speeds can greatly improve printing time. And the quality of exterior support is usually no problem.

speed_travel.label: Travel Speed
speed_travel.description: Speed at which travel moves are done, a well built Ultimaker can reach speeds of 250mm/s. But some machines might miss steps then.

speed_layer_0.label: Bottom Layer Speed
speed_layer_0.description: Print speed for the bottom layer, you want to print the first layer slower so it sticks better to the printer bed.

skirt_speed.label: Skirt Speed
skirt_speed.description: Speed at which the skirt and brim are printed. Normally this is done at the initial layer speed. But sometimes you want to print the skirt at a different speed.

speed_slowdown_layers.label: Amount of Slower Layers
speed_slowdown_layers.description: The first few layers are printed slower then the rest of the object, this to get better adhesion to the printer bed and improve the overall success rate of prints. The speed is gradually increased over these layers. 4 layers of speedup is generally right for most materials and printers.

fill_sparse_density.label: Infill Density
fill_sparse_density.description:
This controls how densely filled the insides of your print will be. For a solid part use 100%, for an empty part use 0%. A value around 20% is usually enough.
This won't affect the outside of the print and only adjusts how strong the part becomes.

fill_pattern.label: Infill Pattern
fill_pattern.description:
Cura defaults to switch between grid and line infill. But with this setting visible you can control this yourself.
The line infill is cross hatched every other layer, while the grid is cross-hatched each layer.

fill_overlap.label: Infill Overlap
fill_overlap.description: Amount of overlap between the infill and the walls. There is a slight overlap with the walls and the infill so the walls connect firmly to the infill.

fill_sparse_thickness.label: Infill Thickness
fill_sparse_thickness.description: Thickness of the sparse infill. This is rounded to a multiple of the layer-thickness and used to print the sparse-infill at possible thicker layers to save printing time.

fill_sparse_combine.label: Infill Layers
fill_sparse_combine.description: Amount of layers that are combined together to form sparse infill.

cool_fan_enabled.label: Enable Cooling Fan
cool_fan_enabled.description: Enable the cooling fan during the print. The extra cooling from the cooling fan is essential during faster prints.

cool_fan_speed.label: Fan Speed
cool_fan_speed.description: Fan speed used for the print cooling fan on the printer head.

cool_fan_speed_min.label: Minimum Fan Speed
cool_fan_speed_min.description: Normally the fan is ran at the minimal fan speed. If the layer is slowed down due to minimal layer time, the fan speed is put somewhere between minimal and maximal fan speed.

cool_fan_speed_max.label: Maximum Fan Speed
cool_fan_speed_max.description: Normally the fan is ran at the minimal fan speed. If the layer is slowed down due to minimal layer time, the fan speed is put somewhere between minimal and maximal fan speed.

cool_fan_full_at_height.label: Fan Full on at Height
cool_fan_full_at_height.description: The height at which the fan is turned on completely. For the layers below this the fan speed is scaled linearly with the fan off at layer 0.

cool_fan_full_layer.label: Fan Full on at Layer
cool_fan_full_layer.description: The layer number at which the fan is turned on completely. For the layers below this the fan speed is scaled linearly with the fan off at layer 0.

cool_min_layer_time.label: Minimal Layer Time
cool_min_layer_time.description: Minimum time spent in a layer, gives the layer time to cool down before the next layer is put on top. If the layer will be placed down too fast the printer will slow down to make sure it has spent at least this amount of seconds printing this layer.

cool_min_speed.label: Minimum Speed
cool_min_speed.description: The minimal layer time can cause the print to slow down so much it starts to ooze. The minimal feedrate protects against this. Even if a print gets slowed down it will never be slower than this minimal speed.

cool_lift_head.label: Lift Head
cool_lift_head.description: Lift the head if the minimal speed is hit because of cool slowdown, and wait the extra time so the minimal layer time is always hit.

support_enable.label: Enable Support
support_enable.description: Enable exterior support material. This will build up structures below the model to prevent the model from sacking.

support_type.label: Type
support_type.description:
The type of support structure.
Grid is very strong and can come off in 1 piece, however, sometimes it is too strong.
Lines are single walled lines that break off one at a time. Which is more work to remove, but as it is less strong it does work better on tricky prints.

support_pattern.label: Support Material Pattern
support_pattern.description:
Cura supports 2 distinct types of support material. First is a grid based support material which is quite solid and can be removed as 1 piece.
The other is a line based support material which has to be pealed of line for line.

support_angle.label: Overhang Angle
support_angle.description: The minimal angle that overhangs need to have to get support. With 0 degree being horizontal and 90 degree being vertical.

support_fill_rate.label: Fill Amount
support_fill_rate.description: Amount of infill structure in the support material, less material gives weaker support which is easier to remove. 15% seems to be a good average.

support_xy_distance.label: X/Y Distance
support_xy_distance.description:
Distance of the support material from the print, in the X/Y directions.
0.7mm gives a nice distance from the print so the support does not stick to the print.

support_z_distance.label: Z Distance
support_z_distance.description:
Distance from the top/bottom of the support to the print. A small gap here makes it easier to remove the support but makes the print a bit uglier.
0.15mm gives a good seperation of the support material.

support_top_distance.label: Top Distance
support_top_distance.description: Distance from the top of the support to the print.

support_bottom_distance.label: Bottom Distance
support_bottom_distance.description: Distance from the print to the bottom of the support.

support_join_distance.label: Join Distance
support_join_distance.description: Maximal distance between support blocks, in the X/Y directions, such that the blocks will merge into a single block.

support_bridge_back.label: Support Bridge
support_bridge_back.description: The amount of area between the layer and the overhang which will generate support. Small values can result in many disconnected suport structures, while large values can cause the support to stick to the print too much.

adhesion_type.label: Type
adhesion_type.description:
Different options that help in preventing corners from lifting due to warping.
Brim adds a single layer thick flat area around your object which is easy to cut off afterwards, and it is the recommended option.
Raft adds a thick raster below the object and a thin interface between this and your object.
(Note that enabling the brim or raft disables the skirt)

skirt_line_count.label: Skirt Line Count
skirt_line_count.description:
The skirt is a line drawn around the object at the first layer. This helps to prime your extruder, and to see if the object fits on your platform.
Setting this to 0 will disable the skirt. Multiple skirt lines can help priming your extruder better for small objects.

skirt_gap.label: Skirt Distance
skirt_gap.description:
The distance between the skirt and the first layer.
This is the minimal distance, multiple skirt lines will be put outwards from this distance.

skirt_minimal_length.label: Skirt Minimum Length
skirt_minimal_length.description:
The minimal length of the skirt, if this minimal length is not reached it will add more skirt lines to reach this minimal length.
Note: If the line count is set to 0 this is ignored.

brim_line_count.label: Brim Line Count
brim_line_count.description: The amount of lines used for a brim, more lines means a larger brim which sticks better, but this also makes your effective print area smaller.

raft_margin.label: Raft Extra Margin
raft_margin.description: If the raft is enabled, this is the extra raft area around the object which is also rafted. Increasing this margin will create a stronger raft while using more material and leaving less area for your print.

raft_line_spacing.label: Raft Line Spacing
raft_line_spacing.description:
Distance between the raft lines.
The first 2 layers of the raft have this amount of spacing between the raft lines.

raft_base_thickness.label: Raft Base Thickness
raft_base_thickness.description: Layer thickness of the first raft layer. This should be a thick layer which attaches firmly to the printer bed.

raft_base_linewidth.label: Raft Base Line Width
raft_base_linewidth.description:
Width of the first raft layer lines.
These should be thick lines to assist in bed adhesion.

raft_base_speed.label: Raft Base Print Speed
raft_base_speed.description: Speed at which the first raft layer is printed. This should be printed quite slow, as the amount of material coming out of the nozzle is quite high.

raft_interface_linewidth.label: Raft Interface Line Width
raft_interface_linewidth.description: Width of the 2nd raft layer lines. These lines should be thinner then the first layer but strong enough to attach the object to.

raft_airgap.label: Raft Air-gap
raft_airgap.description: Gap between the final raft layer and the first layer of the object. Only the first layer is raised by this amount to lower the bonding between the raft layer and the object. Makes it easier to peel off the raft.

raft_surface_layers.label: Raft Surface Layers
raft_surface_layers.description: Amount of surface layers on top of the 2nd raft layer. These are fully filled layers used to print the object on top of. 2 layers usually works fine.

magic_spiralize.label: Spiralize the Outer Contour
magic_spiralize.description:
Spiralize is smoothing out the Z move of the outer edge. This will create a steady Z increase over the whole print. This feature turns a solid object into a single walled print with a solid bottom.
This feature used to be called Joris in older versions.
